image.altText: flames light up night sky behind houses

items.synopsis: Bushfire emergencies are unfolding in multiple states, with residents of Abernethy in NSW told it is "too late to leave".  Fires in Victoria and Tasmania have been downgraded. Follow live.

title.children: Fires in NSW reach emergency level as Victoria, Tasmanian fires downgraded

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Georgia Lenton-Williams AusNet plans to set up a power generator in Loch Sport, as around 2,000 homes remain cut off from the grid in Victoria's Gippsland. AusNet spokesperson Nicci de Ryk told ABC Statewide Drive the power in most homes will be restored by 10pm AEDT tonight. “We've been able to gain access to those impacted areas and we now know the issues we're dealing with,” she said. “There's seven poles that have been affected in the region - three poles completely burnt down, four significantly charred, in addition to some wires down.” She said around 26 homes will remain disconnected. “We’ve got crews going in in the morning to do that permanent fix work, replacing those impacted poles. They are anticipating they’ll have that resolved and move from generator to the existing network structure by the end of tomorrow,” she said. “Broadly, that's the plan to come off generators at some stage once those poles have been rectified.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Power generator to restore power in Gippsland homes

children.content: AusNet plans to set up a power generator in Loch Sport, as around
2,000 homes remain cut off from the grid
the power in most homes will be restored by 10pm AEDT
“We've been able to gain access to those impacted areas and we now know the issues we're dealing with,” she said.
“There's seven poles that have been affected in the region - three poles completely burnt down, four significantly charred, in addition to some wires down.”

“We’ve got crews going in in the morning to do that permanent fix work, replacing those impacted poles. They are anticipating they’ll have that resolved and move from generator to the existing network structure by the end of tomorrow,” she said.
“Broadly, that's the plan to come off generators at some stage once those poles have been rectified.”

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Country Fire Authority Chief Officer Jason Heffernan says this summer will be hotter and drier, and everyone should be prepared. "For East Gippsland communities, if we do see rainfall totals as we've had today, we'll probably seek to pause that bushfire risk, probably for a few weeks, but don't be fooled. Let's not be complacent here ," he says. "The bush will dry out, the warm weather will continue to come about. In fact, we've heard from the Bureau through the Spring Seasonal outlook that we're ... four times more likely to have higher than average temperatures over spring right arcoss Australia. "While it will be a reprieve for firefighters today, [and] it will bring some reprieve to communities from fire conditions for the next couple of weeks, we can't be complacent. We must be constantly thinking about bushfire as we head into this summer." He urges everyone to have a bushfire survival plan and start preparing their property for the coming season.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australians urged to update emergency survival plans

children.content: "For East Gippsland communities, if we do see rainfall totals as we've had today, we'll probably seek to pause that bushfire risk, probably for a few weeks, but don't be fooled.

four times more likely to have higher than average temperatures over spring

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The emergency warnings in Victorian townships Loch Sport and Seacombe have been downgraded to Advice level. "There is currently no threat to you," authorities say. "Stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. Don't get complacent, the situation may change quickly." Authorities advise residents in these areas to continue to monitor weather conditions and warnings as the fire is not yet under control. Earlier, CFA Chief Officer Jason Heffernan said while there were high winds, rain was starting to fall on the fire grounds. "I am very confident that the firefighters are doing everything they can to stop the progress and contain that fire," Heffernan said. "They are very much going to be assisted by the rainfall."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Emergency warnings in Loch Sport and Seacombe downgraded

image.altText: A boat moored by a small jetty with an orange fire burning in the background over the water.

items.synopsis: Firefighters in eastern Victoria say steady rain and a cool change is bringing some relief as they battle two serious bushfires near Briagolong and at Loch Sport on the Gippsland Lakes.

title.children: Rain allowing firefighters to 'gain the upper hand' as they battle two blazes in Gippsland

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair cries while sitting in a police interview room

items.synopsis: Biannca Edmunds has been sentenced to 26 years' jail after a botched assassination plan she hatched with her husband, targeting her ex-partner, resulted in both mens' deaths.

title.children: Judge says woman showed 'extreme' entitlement by plotting to kill her ex-partner over custody issues

image.altText: A man in a burnt out forest

items.synopsis: Despite living in some of the most bushfire-prone parts of the country, these far east Gippsland residents can't contemplate moving anywhere else, even as they watch a fire emergency unfold elsewhere in the region.

title.children: Be prepared or 'bugger off', says Black Summer survivor gearing up for early fire season as region battles emergency

image.altText: Smoke burning over homes

items.synopsis: A bushfire is impacting properties on the New South Wales South Coast and authorities expect the challenging conditions to continue into the night.

title.children: Residents told it's too late to leave as bushfires rage in NSW

image.altText: Anika Wells speaks in parliament.

items.synopsis: The federal Labor minister was diagnosed with an autoimmune disease during her first pregnancy and says, like others with invisible diseases, she does not want people drawing their own conclusions about her illness.

title.children: Why Anika Wells doesn't publicly name her chronic illness

image.altText: A drone shot of a new housing estate, with houses stretching as far as the eye can see

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank has kept interest rates on hold, but more hikes are expected later this year as 550,000 people come off fixed mortgages. The RBA itself warns that could put more people in financial stress, writes Nassim Khadem.

title.children: RBA warns 'solid middle-to-upper-income' people are the new borrowers in financial stress

image.altText: a map of eastern australia showing hot temperatures for those parts

items.synopsis: The frequent spells of early spring heat resulted in Australia's third-warmest September on record since 1910, with a national temperature 2.4C above the climatological average.

title.children: The heat won't stay: Temperatures to drop by as much as 20 degrees in 48 hours

image.altText: Illustration of Australia with night sky and stars in background and yellow circle in middle of Australia.

items.synopsis: On October 14, every Australian will be asked to answer a yes or no question. What you write on the ballot paper will determine whether our constitution is changed for the first time in more than four decades. Here's everything you need to know before you vote.

title.children: Your Voice voting cheat sheet: All your referendum questions, answered

image.altText: A young woman in a fluoro vest with pink glasses standing between trains.

items.synopsis: Chelsea Taylor thought university was the only option after school. But after three unfinished degrees and $30,000 in student debt, she felt "really, really lost" — until she became a train driver.

title.children: After racking up a big student debt, Chelsea became a train driver. She says career advice is limiting teenagers

image.altText: Three people stand in the background, between two purple and white YES signs

items.synopsis: The Yes23 campaign has been asked to keep signs for the Yes vote coloured in purple and white away from Australian Electoral Commission signage.

title.children: Yes23 campaign warned over signs which could 'mislead' voters at polling stations

image.altText: Stan Grant in a suit and short

items.synopsis: Michael Steven Davis, 41, allegedly used his Facebook and Twitter profiles to threaten "serious harm" in May.

title.children: Man accused of abusing Stan Grant online has three charges dropped, offers to apologise

image.altText: Two people sit on a stage smiling, both wearing t-shirts that say Vote No to the Voice of Division

items.synopsis: More than 1,000 vocal No supporters are urged by Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price and Nyunggai Warren Mundine not to get complacent ahead of the historic referendum on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament.

title.children: Price and Mundine issue rallying cry to No crowd in Perth as Voice vote draws closer

image.altText: Composite image of two photos of a man - a selfie with him smoking a cigar and a mugshot. Around him are passport stamps.

items.synopsis: The work undercover operatives and sources do is a key weapon against organised crime. These men say our law enforcement agencies have abandoned them.

title.children: This Australian is sitting in a foreign prison cell. He's ready to come clean about his life undercover

image.altText: Smoke fills the air over mountainous bushland.

items.synopsis: A weather front is bringing rain relief for emergency services tackling a bushfire on Flinders Island that earlier forced evacuations — with residents urged to continue monitoring the "changeable" conditions.

title.children: Rain relief for crews fighting Flinders Island bushfire

image.altText: A smiling baby in a blanket.

items.synopsis: The parents of Alyviah Hayne, who died in 2015, say they'll never recover from their loss. Jake Robert Luscombe will serve at least four years behind bars over the baby's death.

title.children: Family of seven-month-old say they'll 'never heal' as killer is sentenced

image.altText: Anthony Daniels smiles holding up a gold light-up robotic looking head.

items.synopsis: A trove of costumes and props will go under the hammer in a sale of film and television memorabilia worth around $23 million.

title.children: C-3PO's head, Titanic costumes among memorabilia for sale at film auction

image.altText: A girl sits up in bed, hugging her knees to her chest. Her face is blurred by a sheet of tempered glass.

items.synopsis: ABC Investigations has established more than 1,500 people have reported alleged sexual assaults and harassment in mental health wards over the past six years in Australia. It is launching a national crowdsourced investigation into mental health units and is asking people to share their experiences.

title.children: Florence was allegedly raped in her hospital room. She wants her story told to keep others safe

image.altText: An illustration shows several hands, arranged in a circle, holding sheets of paper marked with the Chinese flag.

items.synopsis: Australian law firms acting for the Chinese state are simultaneously completing work for the Australian government, raising concerns over sensitive work being done by those firms.

title.children: Beijing-owned businesses using Australian law firms to advise on takeovers of critical projects

image.altText: A woman smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: The survivor of a terrifying shark attack at Beachport in South Australia's south-east initially thought the animal was another swimmer, her husband says — but he has little doubt his wife will return to the water after recovering in hospital and at home.

title.children: Shark that attacked early morning swimmer 'looked like a white pointer', husband says

image.altText: A teen on the left high fives a senior on the right. Both are wearing bright yellow sweat headbands and black shirts

items.synopsis: With almost one in three Australians reporting feeling lonely, an intergenerational friendship could be the antidote. If you're looking to connect with new friends outside your social bubble, but you're not sure where to start, read on.

title.children: Inspired by Old People's Home for Teenagers? Tap into these ideas to build intergenerational connections

image.altText: Hands holding glasses give cheers, as confetti falls.

items.synopsis: As the government introduces draft legislation to tighten concessions for the largest superannuation account holders, new data reveals 11 more Australians have joined the ranks of account holders with more than $100 million in super.

title.children: Tax office reveals 11 more Australians reporting super balances of more than $100 million

image.altText: Four white men in suits stand side by side.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: US late-night hosts return after five-month absence and NT police pick up large volume of surgical scissors using metal-detecting wands. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: Split screen image of a woman and a man on ABC's Q+A.

items.synopsis: As Senator Malarndirri McCarthy reveals the moment she felt most "disempowered", a debate focused on who the Voice will help takes over Q+A.

title.children: 'Disadvantage' locked into the constitution or 'significant moment'? Voice debate heats up on Q+A

image.altText: Kacey and Layne stand together smiling on a suburban street.

items.synopsis: Less than half of the federal government's promised urgent care clinics have opened, months after the policy was supposed to be delivered.

title.children: After waiting six hours in an emergency department, Kasey is wondering where her city's Urgent Care Clinic is

image.altText: A line of utes entering a gate.

items.synopsis: On Monday evening an 18-year-old man handed himself in to Wagga Wagga police station where he was charged with three offences, including assault occasioning actual bodily harm.

title.children: Teenager charged after man allegedly set on fire at Deniliquin Ute Muster over the long weekend

image.altText: Trees in silhouette in front of a lightning strike.

items.synopsis: Tens of thousands of homes and businesses have been left without power across South Australia following a night of wild weather that included intense lightning and very strong wind gusts.

title.children: Emergency volunteer suffers electric shock as 'lightning show' cuts power to thousands of SA properties

image.altText: A man in a woven headdress stands in a field, looking solemn

items.synopsis: Japan's Ainu people have their own history, languages and culture. But, as the victims of colonialism, assimilation and discrimination, much of that identity has been lost. This is the story of their fight to be recognised.

title.children: For years, Japan tried to keep their existence a secret. But the Ainu people refuse to disappear

image.altText: Thanasi Kokkinakis crouches down and leans his head on his racquet

items.synopsis: The Australian Open will start on a Sunday in 2024, becoming a 15-day event in a bid to reduce the pressure on players and fans from late-night finishes.

title.children: Australian Open set for shake-up to eliminate 'ridiculously late' finishes

image.altText: Taylor Adams in tears hugs Darcy Moore

items.synopsis: AFL premiership coach Craig McRae says all Collingwood players who featured during the season deserve medals after the club's grand final triumph.

title.children: 'It just seems wrong': More Magpies deserving of AFL Premiership medals says Cox, McRae

image.altText: An aerial shot of the Gorgon gas project on the coast of Western Australia.

items.synopsis: Australia may be a quarry to the world, and the mining of its natural resources might underpin our national budget. But we can and must demand better corporate ethics than this, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: A 'sham' workforce in WA has exposed the shadowy ways of global oil and gas — and workers are paying the price

image.altText: City office-workers and passers-by watch the ASX board in Sydney

items.synopsis: The local share market suffered heavy losses as investors bet on interest rates staying higher for longer, while the Australian dollar slumped to its weakest level since November, despite increased bets the Reserve Bank will lift interest rates again in the next few months.

title.children: ASX wipes out all its gains of 2023, RBA keeps rates on hold but doesn't rule out future increase — as it happened

image.altText: A pilot stands beside heavily-armed rebels in Papua.

items.synopsis: Rebels were armed with military-grade weapons and arrows when a battle broke out between them and a joint military and police force, with the group saying the deaths of their fighters would not lead to their surrender.

title.children: Members of Papuan rebel group behind kidnapping of New Zealand pilot killed in clashes with security forces

image.altText: Houses under construction in the background with building materials in the foreground.

items.synopsis: A group of councils in the Loddon Mallee region is working to jointly appoint a dedicated regional housing officer, as part of a region-wide housing action plan.

title.children: Councils band together to tackle housing crisis crippling regional Victoria
